title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: psychinterpreter package automatically interprets psychometric analysis results using Large Language Models (LLMs). LLMs AI systems (like ChatGPT, Claude, open-source alternatives) can understand generate human-like text. Instead manually examining complex statistical output guessing patterns represent, get clear, human-readable interpretations actionable insights. Currently supported analyses: Factor Analysis - Interpret factor loadings suggest meaningful factor names Planned analysis classes: Gaussian Mixture Models - Interpret cluster profiles Item Response Theory (IRT) - Interpret item diagnostics Cognitive Diagnostic Models (CDM) - Interpret Q-matrix patterns Use package : run psychometric analysis (e.g., factor analysis, clustering) Want automated, data-driven interpretations results Need quickly understand complex patterns data

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: starting, make sure : Analysis results - psych::fa(), lavaan::efa(), similar functions Variable descriptions - brief explanations variable measures language model - recommend Ollama (free, runs locally, offers cloud-powered models Ollama account)

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: ’s complete workflow factor analysis using Big Five personality data just lines:
code: library(psychinterpreter) library(psych) library(ollamar)  # 1. Run factor analysis fa_result <- psych::fa(bfi[,1:25], nfactors = 5, rotate = "oblimin")  # 2. Describe your variables var_info <- data.frame(   variable = c("A1", "A2", "A3", ...),   description = c("Am indifferent to others", "Inquire about others", ...) )  # 3. Get LLM interpretation interpretation <- interpret(   model_fit = fa_result,   variable_info = var_info,   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # 4. View results print(interpretation) plot(interpretation)

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: tutorial demonstrates package using factor analysis, workflow applies analysis types become available. Let’s walk complete example using Big Five Inventory (BFI) personality data. Load packages ’ll need: BFI dataset contains 25 personality items measuring Big Five traits. ’s data looks like: item descriptions: Perform standard exploratory factor analysis 5 factors: View factor loadings: Create data frame mapping variable names descriptions: Now use interpret() get automatic factor interpretations: Note First time using Ollama? Install Ollama ollama.com ollamar package: install.packages("ollamar") Pull model: ollamar::pull("gpt-oss:20b-cloud") Start Ollama server running interpret() Print interpretation report: output shows: - Suggested factor names - variables load factor - brief interpretation factor represents View suggested factor names: Create visual representation factor loadings:  plot shows variables load strongly factor, making easy see factor structure glance. Save interpretation file:
code: # Install pacman if needed for easy package loading if (!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman")  # Load packages pacman::p_load(   "psychinterpreter",  # This package   "psych",             # For factor analysis   "DT",        # For nice tables   "dplyr",             # For data manipulation   "pander"             # package for pretty printing ) # Load Big Five Inventory data data("bfi") data("bfi.dictionary")  # Keep only the 25 personality items (remove demographics) bfi_items <- bfi[, 1:25] bfi_dict <- bfi.dictionary[1:25, ] head(bfi_items, 5) |>   as.data.frame() |>    DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE)) bfi_dict |>   select(Item) |>   as.data.frame() |>   DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE)) fa_result <- psych::fa(   bfi_items,   nfactors = 5,   rotate = "oblimin",  # Oblique rotation   fm = "ml"            # Maximum likelihood ) # Extract and display loadings loadings_matrix <- unclass(fa_result$loadings) |>    as.data.frame()  round(loadings_matrix, 2) |>    DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE)) variable_info <- data.frame(   variable = rownames(bfi_dict),   description = as.character(bfi_dict$Item),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  head(variable_info, 10) |>    DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE)) interpretation <- interpret(   model_fit = fa_result,   variable_info = variable_info,   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" ) FACTOR ANALYSIS INTERPRETATION ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  Number of factors: 5 Loading cutoff: 0.3 LLM used: ollama - gpt-oss:20b-cloud Tokens:   Input: 1780   Output: 4887 Elapsed time: 21  SUGGESTED FACTOR NAMES ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  • Factor 1 (9.6%): Negative Emotionality • Factor 2 (7.7%): Warmhearted Sociality • Factor 3 (7.4%): Introverted Withdrawal • Factor 4 (7.7%): Conscientious Precision • Factor 5 (6.3%): Intellectual Curiosity  Total variance explained: 38.7%  DETAILED FACTOR INTERPRETATIONS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  Factor 1 (ML2) - Negative Emotionality Number of significant loadings: 5 Variance explained: 9.65%  Variables:   1. N1, Get angry easily. (Positive, Very Strong, .852)   2. N2, Get irritated easily. (Positive, Very Strong, .817)   3. N3, Have frequent mood swings. (Positive, Strong, .665)   4. N5, Panic easily. (Positive, Moderate, .439)   5. N4, Often feel blue. (Positive, Moderate, .413)  LLM Interpretation: ML2 captures core aspects of negative emotionality. The factor is dominated by very high loadings on the five neuroticism items (N1–N5), which represent anger, irritation, mood swings, sadness, and panic. These items share a common, volatile affective dimension that is absent in other factors. The near‑zero loadings on the other scales demonstrate discriminant validity, confirming that ML2 is distinct from social, conscientious, or open‑minded domains. In behavioral terms, individuals high on ML2 are likely to experience frequent mood shifts, feel easily upset, and respond with anxiety in challenging situations, whereas those low on the factor exhibit greater emotional steadiness. These affective fluctuations also interact with social context, often impairing interpersonal interactions and increasing vulnerability to stress‑related health issues over time.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Factor 2 (ML5) - Warmhearted Sociality Number of significant loadings: 7 Variance explained: 7.69%  Variables:   1. A3, Know how to comfort others. (Positive, Strong, .668)   2. A2, Inquire about others' well-being. (Positive, Strong, .603)   3. A5, Make people feel at ease. (Positive, Strong, .577)   4. A4, Love children. (Positive, Moderate, .456)   5. E4, Make friends easily. (Positive, Weak, .362)   6. A1, Am indifferent to the feelings of others. (Negative, Weak, -.360)   7. E3, Know how to captivate people. (Positive, Weak, .303)  LLM Interpretation: ML5 reflects a socially caring disposition. The strongest loadings come from agreeableness items that probe nurturing and supportive behavior (A2, A3, A4, A5). These items describe inquiring about others’ well‑being, comforting people, loving children, and making others feel at ease, which together form a cohesive empathic inclination. The moderate negative loadings on extraversion items (E3, E4) highlight a subtle distinction: while individuals high on ML5 are warm toward others, they may not necessarily seek admiration or assume leadership roles. The factor’s discriminant validity is evident from the lack of substantial loadings on the conscientiousness, neuroticism, or openness dimensions, underscoring that ML5 is a distinct domain of interpersonal connectedness. High scores predict prosocial behavior, cooperative teamwork, and a tendency toward emotional support in both personal and workplace contexts.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Factor 3 (ML1) - Introverted Withdrawal Number of significant loadings: 7 Variance explained: 7.36%  Variables:   1. E2, Find it difficult to approach others. (Positive, Strong, .667)   2. E1, Don't talk a lot. (Positive, Strong, .565)   3. E4, Make friends easily. (Negative, Strong, -.527)   4. N4, Often feel blue. (Positive, Moderate, .420)   5. E5, Take charge. (Negative, Weak, -.394)   6. O4, Spend time reflecting on things. (Positive, Weak, .357)   7. E3, Know how to captivate people. (Negative, Weak, -.341)  LLM Interpretation: ML1 is the classic extraversion (introversion) axis. Its high positive loadings on E1 (‘Don’t talk a lot’) and E2 (‘Find it difficult to approach others’) capture a withdrawal tendency, while the negative loadings on social‑engagement items (E3, E4, E5) confirm the opposite direction of affective and behavioral assertiveness. The factor also shows little cross‑loading on the agreeableness, conscientiousness, or openness scales, suggesting clear discriminant validity. In practical terms, individuals with high ML1 scores tend to be reserved, prefer solitary activities, and may experience social anxiety. Conversely, low scores indicate sociability, assertive leadership, and comfort in large groups. This factor therefore distinguishes the sociality dimension from affective stability and intellectual curiosity, and aligns closely with the extraversion–introversion continuum widely used in personality assessment. Such introverts tend to seek solitary stimulation and may excel in analytical or reflective tasks.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Factor 4 (ML3) - Conscientious Precision Number of significant loadings: 5 Variance explained: 7.71%  Variables:   1. C4, Do things in a half-way manner. (Negative, Strong, -.643)   2. C2, Continue until everything is perfect. (Positive, Strong, .638)   3. C5, Waste my time. (Negative, Strong, -.570)   4. C3, Do things according to a plan. (Positive, Strong, .564)   5. C1, Am exacting in my work. (Positive, Strong, .532)  LLM Interpretation: ML3 corresponds to conscientiousness with a focus on planning and perfection. Strong positive loadings on C1 (exacting), C2 (perfect), and C3 (plan) indicate a firm commitment to order and quality. The negative loadings on C4 (‘half‑way’) and C5 (‘waste’) demonstrate the opposite, tendency toward laxity or procrastination. This contrast gives ML3 an internally coherent structure that separates disciplined, rule‑oriented work from sloppiness. It has negligible loadings on other personality domains, ensuring discriminant validity. In everyday behavior, people scoring high on ML3 are meticulous, methodical, and strive for high standards, whereas low scorers are more flexible, less detail‑oriented, and may tolerate inefficiency. Thus ML3 captures the spectrum between meticulousness and complacency within conscientiousness. This dimension helps educators design feedback regimens that nurture discipline while avoiding over‑rigidity, and is predictive of attention‑to‑detail tasks in professional settings.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Factor 5 (ML4) - Intellectual Curiosity Number of significant loadings: 6 Variance explained: 6.25%  Variables:   1. O3, Carry the conversation to a higher level. (Positive, Strong, .633)   2. O1, Am full of ideas. (Positive, Strong, .534)   3. O5, Will not probe deeply into a subject. (Negative, Strong, -.522)   4. O2, Avoid difficult reading material. (Negative, Moderate, -.441)   5. O4, Spend time reflecting on things. (Positive, Weak, .379)   6. E3, Know how to captivate people. (Positive, Weak, .315)  LLM Interpretation: ML4 embodies intellectual curiosity. Positive loadings on O1 (‘full of ideas’), O3 (‘carry conversation to higher level’), and O4 (‘spend time reflecting’) capture the tendency to generate, explore, and deepen concepts. The negative loadings on O2 (‘avoid difficult reading’) and O5 (‘will not probe deeply’) contrast a preference for superficial or non‑challenging material with a drive for abstract thought. Weak E3 and E5 loadings suggest that this dimension is distinct from extraversion and assertiveness. Thus ML4 distinguishes an open‑minded, reflective orientation from a more guarded or pragmatic stance. High scores predict openness to new experiences, imaginative problem‑solving, and engagement in academic or creative pursuits, whereas low scores indicate a preference for concrete facts and routine activities. These traits foster learning environments where questioning norms is encouraged and novel solutions thrive.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ print(interpretation) FACTOR ANALYSIS INTERPRETATION ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  Number of factors: 5 Loading cutoff: 0.3 LLM used: ollama - gpt-oss:20b-cloud Tokens:   Input: 1780   Output: 4887 Elapsed time: 21  SUGGESTED FACTOR NAMES ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  • Factor 1 (9.6%): Negative Emotionality • Factor 2 (7.7%): Warmhearted Sociality • Factor 3 (7.4%): Introverted Withdrawal • Factor 4 (7.7%): Conscientious Precision • Factor 5 (6.3%): Intellectual Curiosity  Total variance explained: 38.7%  DETAILED FACTOR INTERPRETATIONS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  Factor 1 (ML2) - Negative Emotionality Number of significant loadings: 5 Variance explained: 9.65%  Variables:   1. title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: Load packages ’ll need:
code: # Install pacman if needed for easy package loading if (!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman")  # Load packages pacman::p_load(   "psychinterpreter",  # This package   "psych",             # For factor analysis   "DT",        # For nice tables   "dplyr",             # For data manipulation   "pander"             # package for pretty printing )

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: BFI dataset contains 25 personality items measuring Big Five traits. ’s data looks like: item descriptions:
code: # Load Big Five Inventory data data("bfi") data("bfi.dictionary")  # Keep only the 25 personality items (remove demographics) bfi_items <- bfi[, 1:25] bfi_dict <- bfi.dictionary[1:25, ] head(bfi_items, 5) |>   as.data.frame() |>    DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE)) bfi_dict |>   select(Item) |>   as.data.frame() |>   DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE))

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: Perform standard exploratory factor analysis 5 factors: View factor loadings:
code: fa_result <- psych::fa(   bfi_items,   nfactors = 5,   rotate = "oblimin",  # Oblique rotation   fm = "ml"            # Maximum likelihood ) # Extract and display loadings loadings_matrix <- unclass(fa_result$loadings) |>    as.data.frame()  round(loadings_matrix, 2) |>    DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE))

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: Create data frame mapping variable names descriptions:
code: variable_info <- data.frame(   variable = rownames(bfi_dict),   description = as.character(bfi_dict$Item),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  head(variable_info, 10) |>    DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE))

The negative loadings on O2 (‘avoid difficult reading’) and O5 (‘will not probe deeply’) contrast a preference for superficial or non‑challenging material with a drive for abstract thought. Weak E3 and E5 loadings suggest that this dimension is distinct from extraversion and assertiveness. Thus ML4 distinguishes an open‑minded, reflective orientation from a more guarded or pragmatic stance. High scores predict openness to new experiences, imaginative problem‑solving, and engagement in academic or creative pursuits, whereas low scores indicate a preference for concrete facts and routine activities. These traits foster learning environments where questioning norms is encouraged and novel solutions thrive.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: Print interpretation report: output shows: - Suggested factor names - variables load factor - brief interpretation factor represents View suggested factor names:
code: print(interpretation) FACTOR ANALYSIS INTERPRETATION ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  Number of factors: 5 Loading cutoff: 0.3 LLM used: ollama - gpt-oss:20b-cloud Tokens:   Input: 1780   Output: 4887 Elapsed time: 21  SUGGESTED FACTOR NAMES ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  • Factor 1 (9.6%): Negative Emotionality • Factor 2 (7.7%): Warmhearted Sociality • Factor 3 (7.4%): Introverted Withdrawal • Factor 4 (7.7%): Conscientious Precision • Factor 5 (6.3%): Intellectual Curiosity  Total variance explained: 38.7%  DETAILED FACTOR INTERPRETATIONS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  Factor 1 (ML2) - Negative Emotionality Number of significant loadings: 5 Variance explained: 9.65%  Variables:   1. N1, Get angry easily. (Positive, Very Strong, .852)   2. N2, Get irritated easily. (Positive, Very Strong, .817)   3. N3, Have frequent mood swings. (Positive, Strong, .665)   4. N5, Panic easily. (Positive, Moderate, .439)   5. N4, Often feel blue. (Positive, Moderate, .413)  LLM Interpretation: ML2 captures core aspects of negative emotionality. The factor is dominated by very high loadings on the five neuroticism items (N1–N5), which represent anger, irritation, mood swings, sadness, and panic. These items share a common, volatile affective dimension that is absent in other factors. The near‑zero loadings on the other scales demonstrate discriminant validity, confirming that ML2 is distinct from social, conscientious, or open‑minded domains. In behavioral terms, individuals high on ML2 are likely to experience frequent mood shifts, feel easily upset, and respond with anxiety in challenging situations, whereas those low on the factor exhibit greater emotional steadiness. These affective fluctuations also interact with social context, often impairing interpersonal interactions and increasing vulnerability to stress‑related health issues over time.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Factor 2 (ML5) - Warmhearted Sociality Number of significant loadings: 7 Variance explained: 7.69%  Variables:   1. A3, Know how to comfort others. (Positive, Strong, .668)   2. A2, Inquire about others' well-being. (Positive, Strong, .603)   3. A5, Make people feel at ease. (Positive, Strong, .577)   4. A4, Love children. (Positive, Moderate, .456)   5. E4, Make friends easily. (Positive, Weak, .362)   6. A1, Am indifferent to the feelings of others. (Negative, Weak, -.360)   7. E3, Know how to captivate people. (Positive, Weak, .303)  LLM Interpretation: ML5 reflects a socially caring disposition. The strongest loadings come from agreeableness items that probe nurturing and supportive behavior (A2, A3, A4, A5). These items describe inquiring about others’ well‑being, comforting people, loving children, and making others feel at ease, which together form a cohesive empathic inclination. The moderate negative loadings on extraversion items (E3, E4) highlight a subtle distinction: while individuals high on ML5 are warm toward others, they may not necessarily seek admiration or assume leadership roles. The factor’s discriminant validity is evident from the lack of substantial loadings on the conscientiousness, neuroticism, or openness dimensions, underscoring that ML5 is a distinct domain of interpersonal connectedness. High scores predict prosocial behavior, cooperative teamwork, and a tendency toward emotional support in both personal and workplace contexts.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Factor 3 (ML1) - Introverted Withdrawal Number of significant loadings: 7 Variance explained: 7.36%  Variables:   1. E2, Find it difficult to approach others. (Positive, Strong, .667)   2. E1, Don't talk a lot. (Positive, Strong, .565)   3. E4, Make friends easily. (Negative, Strong, -.527)   4. N4, Often feel blue. (Positive, Moderate, .420)   5. E5, Take charge. (Negative, Weak, -.394)   6. O4, Spend time reflecting on things. (Positive, Weak, .357)   7. E3, Know how to captivate people. (Negative, Weak, -.341)  LLM Interpretation: ML1 is the classic extraversion (introversion) axis. Its high positive loadings on E1 (‘Don’t talk a lot’) and E2 (‘Find it difficult to approach others’) capture a withdrawal tendency, while the negative loadings on social‑engagement items (E3, E4, E5) confirm the opposite direction of affective and behavioral assertiveness. The factor also shows little cross‑loading on the agreeableness, conscientiousness, or openness scales, suggesting clear discriminant validity. In practical terms, individuals with high ML1 scores tend to be reserved, prefer solitary activities, and may experience social anxiety. Conversely, low scores indicate sociability, assertive leadership, and comfort in large groups. This factor therefore distinguishes the sociality dimension from affective stability and intellectual curiosity, and aligns closely with the extraversion–introversion continuum widely used in personality assessment. Such introverts tend to seek solitary stimulation and may excel in analytical or reflective tasks.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Factor 4 (ML3) - Conscientious Precision Number of significant loadings: 5 Variance explained: 7.71%  Variables:   1. C4, Do things in a half-way manner. (Negative, Strong, -.643)   2. C2, Continue until everything is perfect. (Positive, Strong, .638)   3. C5, Waste my time. (Negative, Strong, -.570)   4. C3, Do things according to a plan. (Positive, Strong, .564)   5. C1, Am exacting in my work. (Positive, Strong, .532)  LLM Interpretation: ML3 corresponds to conscientiousness with a focus on planning and perfection. Strong positive loadings on C1 (exacting), C2 (perfect), and C3 (plan) indicate a firm commitment to order and quality. The negative loadings on C4 (‘half‑way’) and C5 (‘waste’) demonstrate the opposite, tendency toward laxity or procrastination. This contrast gives ML3 an internally coherent structure that separates disciplined, rule‑oriented work from sloppiness. It has negligible loadings on other personality domains, ensuring discriminant validity. In everyday behavior, people scoring high on ML3 are meticulous, methodical, and strive for high standards, whereas low scorers are more flexible, less detail‑oriented, and may tolerate inefficiency. Thus ML3 captures the spectrum between meticulousness and complacency within conscientiousness. This dimension helps educators design feedback regimens that nurture discipline while avoiding over‑rigidity, and is predictive of attention‑to‑detail tasks in professional settings.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Factor 5 (ML4) - Intellectual Curiosity Number of significant loadings: 6 Variance explained: 6.25%  Variables:   1. O3, Carry the conversation to a higher level. (Positive, Strong, .633)   2. O1, Am full of ideas. (Positive, Strong, .534)   3. O5, Will not probe deeply into a subject. (Negative, Strong, -.522)   4. O2, Avoid difficult reading material. (Negative, Moderate, -.441)   5. O4, Spend time reflecting on things. (Positive, Weak, .379)   6. E3, Know how to captivate people. (Positive, Weak, .315)  LLM Interpretation: ML4 embodies intellectual curiosity. Positive loadings on O1 (‘full of ideas’), O3 (‘carry conversation to higher level’), and O4 (‘spend time reflecting’) capture the tendency to generate, explore, and deepen concepts. The negative loadings on O2 (‘avoid difficult reading’) and O5 (‘will not probe deeply’) contrast a preference for superficial or non‑challenging material with a drive for abstract thought. Weak E3 and E5 loadings suggest that this dimension is distinct from extraversion and assertiveness. Thus ML4 distinguishes an open‑minded, reflective orientation from a more guarded or pragmatic stance. High scores predict openness to new experiences, imaginative problem‑solving, and engagement in academic or creative pursuits, whereas low scores indicate a preference for concrete facts and routine activities. These traits foster learning environments where questioning norms is encouraged and novel solutions thrive.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ interpretation$suggested_names |>   unlist() |>  data.frame(Suggested_Factor_Name = _) |>   DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE), colnames = "Suggested Factor Name")

text: Q: LLM interpretation seems wrong? LLM bases interpretations variable descriptions statistical results. can: Provide better, descriptive variable descriptions Use bigger LLM. Small models may struggle task structured output requirements. Adjust cutoff hide_low_loadings parameters change results included Add context additional_info parameter Q: Can use different LLMs? Yes! package supports providers supported ellmer package, example: Ollama (local, free): llm_provider = "ollama" OpenAI (API key required): llm_provider = "openai" Anthropic Claude (API key required): llm_provider = "anthropic" Q: set API keys OpenAI Anthropic? Also refer documentation ellmer https://ellmer.tidyverse.org/ package.

title: Usage Patterns of the interpret() Function
text: use Ollama, need make sure start server running . Test connection: use model “gpt-oss:20b-cloud”, needs installed. Since cloud-powered model, need account Ollama logged run model.
code: packages <- c(   "psychinterpreter",   "ellmer",   "ollamar",   "psych",   "lavaan",   "mirt",   "dplyr",   "here",   "DT",   "pander" ) # Load required packages using pacman if (!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman") Loading required package: pacman pacman::p_load(char = packages) #!/bin/bash  # Check if port 11434 (default Ollama port) is in use if netstat -ano | grep 11434 > /dev/null; then     echo "Ollama is already running." else     echo "Starting Ollama..."     ollama serve fi Ollama is already running. system2("ollama serve", wait = FALSE) Warning in system2("ollama serve", wait = FALSE): '"ollama serve"' not found # test the connection to the Ollama server ollamar::test_connection() Ollama local server running <httr2_response> GET http://localhost:11434/ Status: 200 OK Content-Type: text/plain Body: In memory (17 bytes) # pull the model from ollama if it is not already installed if (!"gpt-oss:20b-cloud" %in% ollamar::list_models()$name) {   ollamar::pull("gpt-oss:20b-cloud") }

title: Usage Patterns of the interpret() Function
text: Automatically extracts model components fitted objects. custom data structures manual extraction. FA, provide loadings (required) optionally factor_cor_mat: Reuse chat session across analyses save tokens. can check total global token usage:
code: interpret(   model_fit = fa_model,   variable_info = var_info,   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud",   word_limit = 50 ) ℹ Starting fa interpretation... ℹ Creating temporary chat session... ℹ Building prompt... ℹ Querying LLM... ℹ Parsing LLM response... ℹ Creating diagnostics... ℹ Building report... ✔ Interpretation complete! title: CLAUDE.md
text: Purpose: Quick reference Claude Code helping users psychinterpreter R package. technical/architectural details: See dev/DEVELOPER_GUIDE.md Status: Phase 2 Refactoring Complete (2025-11-10) - See dev/DEVELOPER_GUIDE.md section 4.2 details IMPORTANT API CHANGES: - Phase 1 (2025-11-09): - model_fit renamed fit_results - llm_provider llm_model renamed provider model - New config objects: llm_args(), fa_args(), output_args() - Phase 2 (2025-11-10): - interpret_fa() removed entirely (functionality now S3 generic build_model_data()) - New architecture: interpret() → interpret_core() → build_model_data.fa() - 169 tests passing new S3 generic system

title: CLAUDE.md
text: : Automates interpretation exploratory factor analysis (EFA) results using Large Language Models via ellmer package. Main Entry Points: - interpret() - Universal generic (public API interpretations) - chat_session() - Create persistent LLM session (saves ~40-60% tokens multiple analyses) Standards Examples/Tests: - Always use provider = "ollama" model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" - LLM tests: word_limit = 20 (minimum allowed) token efficiency Documentation Structure: - CLAUDE.md (file): Usage guide quick reference Claude Code sessions - dev/DEVELOPER_GUIDE.md: Technical architecture implementation details maintainers - dev/TESTING_GUIDELINES.md: Testing standards patterns - dev/templates/: Ready--copy code templates implementing new model types (GM, IRT, CDM) - dev/MODEL_IMPLEMENTATION_GUIDE.md: Conceptual guide new model type implementation

title: CLAUDE.md
code: devtools::install_github("username/psychinterpreter")

title: CLAUDE.md
code: library(psychinterpreter)  # 1. Run factor analysis fa_result <- psych::fa(data, nfactors = 3)  # 2. Prepare variable descriptions var_info <- data.frame(   variable = c("var1", "var2", ...),   description = c("Description of variable 1", "Description of variable 2", ...) )  # 3. Get interpretation interpretation <- interpret(   fit_results = fa_result,   variable_info = var_info,   provider = "ollama",   model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # 4. View and export results print(interpretation)                                    # Print report plot(interpretation)                                     # Visualize loadings export_interpretation(interpretation, "results.md", "md") # Export

title: CLAUDE.md
code: # Create session once (saves ~40-60% tokens) chat <- chat_session(   model_type = "fa",   provider = "ollama",   model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # Reuse for multiple interpretations result1 <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = fa1, variable_info = vars1) result2 <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = fa2, variable_info = vars2) result3 <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = fa3, variable_info = vars3)  # Check cumulative token usage print(chat)

title: CLAUDE.md
text: interpret() function accepts different input types. arguments named prevent confusion.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Supported model types: - psych::fa(), psych::principal() - lavaan::cfa(), lavaan::sem(), lavaan::efa() - mirt::mirt()
code: # Automatically extracts loadings from model objects interpret(   model_fit = psych::fa(...),        # Or lavaan::efa(), mirt::mirt(), etc.   variable_info = var_info,   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )

title: CLAUDE.md
code: # For custom data structures # Both loadings and Phi can be matrices or data.frames interpret(   model_fit = list(     loadings = loadings_matrix,     Phi = correlation_matrix          # Optional (for oblique rotations)   ),   variable_info = var_info,   model_type = "fa",                  # REQUIRED for lists   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )

title: CLAUDE.md
text: use : - Single analysis: Pattern 1 (fitted model) - simplest - Multiple analyses: Pattern 3 (chat session) - efficient - Custom data: Pattern 2 (structured list)
code: # Create session once chat <- chat_session(model_type = "fa", provider = "ollama", model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud")  # Use with any model_fit type interpret(chat_session = chat, model_fit = fa_result, variable_info = var_info) interpret(chat_session = chat, model_fit = loadings_list, variable_info = var_info)  # Structured list works too

title: CLAUDE.md
code: # View full prompts and responses interpret(..., echo = "all")  # Check JSON parsing with raw response (same function) interpret(..., echo = "all")

title: CLAUDE.md
code: # Control verbosity interpret(..., silent = 0)  # Show report + messages (default) interpret(..., silent = 1)  # Messages only, no report interpret(..., silent = 2)  # Completely silent  # Output formats interpret(..., output_format = "text")      # Default: plain text interpret(..., output_format = "markdown")  # Markdown format

title: LLM-powered interpretation for psychometric analyses
text: 🤖 LLM-Powered Interpretation: Generate human-readable factor names interpretations using state---art language models via ‘ellmer’ package psych::fa() psych::principal() results lavaan::cfa(), lavaan::sem(), lavaan::efa() results mirt::mirt() multidimensional IRT results Auto-extracts loadings factor correlations 📊 Comprehensive Reports: Automatically generate detailed reports text markdown format 📈 Visualizations: Create publication-ready heatmaps factor loadings suggested factor names 💾 Multi-Format Export: Export results TXT MD formats 🎯 Provider Agnostic: Works OpenAI, Anthropic, Google Gemini, Azure, Ollama, via ‘ellmer’ 🔄 Persistent Chat Sessions: Reuse LLM sessions across multiple analyses save tokens reduce costs

code: library(psychinterpreter) library(psych)  # Run factor analysis fa_result <- fa(bfi[,1:25], nfactors = 5, rotate = "oblimin")  # Create variable information var_info <- data.frame(   variable = rownames(bfi.dictionary[1:25,]),   description = bfi.dictionary$Item[1:25] )  # Interpret directly from model object results <- interpret(fa_result,                      variable_info = var_info,                      provider = "ollama",                      model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud")

title: LLM-powered interpretation for psychometric analyses
text: Use persistent chat sessions save tokens analyzing multiple datasets:
code: # Create reusable chat session chat <- chat_session(model_type = "fa", provider = "ollama", model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud")  # Run multiple interpretations (saves ~40-60% tokens) result1 <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = fa_result1, variable_info = var_info1, silent = 2) result2 <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = fa_result2, variable_info = var_info2) result3 <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = fa_result3, variable_info = var_info3)  # Check cumulative token usage print(chat)

title: Create Analysis Chat Session — chat_session
text: model_type Character. Type analysis: "fa" (factor analysis), "gm" (gaussian mixture), "irt" (item response theory), "cdm" (cognitive diagnosis model) provider Character. LLM provider (e.g., "anthropic", "openai", "ollama") model Character. Model name (e.g., "claude-haiku-4-5-20251001") system_prompt Character NULL. Optional custom system prompt text override model-specific default system prompt. Use provide institution- project-specific framing LLM (e.g., preferred terminology, audience level, reporting conventions). NULL, model-specific default system prompt used (default = NULL). params List. ellmer parameters (temperature, etc.). Default uses ellmer::params() echo Character. Echo level ("none", "output", ""). Default "none" word_limit Integer. Word limit interpretations (used system_prompt NULL). Default 100.

title: Create Analysis Chat Session — chat_session
text: chat_session object containing persistent chat session

title: Create Analysis Chat Session — chat_session
text: chat_session object stores: persistent ellmer chat session model-specific system prompt already loaded Model type, provider, model information Token usage tracking (cumulative input/output tokens across interpretations) Session metadata (number interpretations run, creation timestamp) allows efficient reuse across multiple interpretations without resending system prompt time. Token Tracking Note: package tracks per-interpretation token counts using roles returned ellmer::chat$get_tokens() (user/assistant). providers ellmer wrapper consistently expose system/system_prompt token counts (appears upstream limitation/bug). avoid incorrect cumulative accounting (double-counting negative accumulation), chat_session intentionally include system_prompt tokens package-level cumulative counters (total_input_tokens / total_output_tokens). require provider-specific view includes system prompt tokens, call chat$chat$get_tokens(include_system_prompt = TRUE) directly — note results may vary across providers.

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
text: fit_results One : Fitted model object: psych package: fa(), principal() lavaan package: cfa(), sem(), efa() mirt package: mirt() Structured list model components: FA: list(loadings = matrix, factor_cor_mat = matrix) list(loadings = matrix) (loadings factor_cor_mat can matrices data.frames) GM: yet implemented IRT: yet implemented CDM: yet implemented variable_info Dataframe 'variable' 'description' columns describing variables. chat_session Optional. chat_session object created chat_session token-efficient multi-analysis workflows (default = NULL). model_type Character. Type analysis ("fa", "gm", "irt", "cdm"). Required using structured list without chat_session. Automatically inferred chat_session provided (default = NULL). provider Character. LLM provider (e.g., "openai", "anthropic", "ollama", "gemini"). Required chat_session NULL. Top-level convenience parameter (default = NULL). model Character. Specific model use (e.g., "gpt-4o-mini", "claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022", "gemma2:9b"). NULL, uses provider default. Top-level convenience parameter (default = NULL). llm_args List llm_args object. LLM configuration settings. Can created llm_args passed plain list. Contains: system_prompt, params, word_limit, interpretation_guidelines, additional_info, echo. provider/model provided top-level, override values llm_args (default = NULL). fa_args List fa_args object. Factor analysis configuration settings. Can created fa_args passed plain list. Contains: cutoff, n_emergency, hide_low_loadings, sort_loadings, factor_cor_mat (default = NULL). output_args List output_args object. Output configuration settings. Can created output_args passed plain list. Contains: format, heading_level, suppress_heading, max_line_length, silent (default = NULL). ... Additional arguments passed model-specific methods.

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
text: Pattern 1: Fitted Model Object Automatically extracts model components fitted objects. Pattern 2: Structured List custom data structures manual extraction. FA, provide loadings (required) optionally factor_cor_mat: Pattern 3: Chat Session (Token-Efficient) Reuse chat session across analyses save tokens.
code: interpret(   fit_results = fa_model,   variable_info = var_info,   provider = "ollama",   model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" ) interpret(   fit_results = list(     loadings = loadings_matrix,     factor_cor_mat = factor_cor_mat   ),   variable_info = var_info,   model_type = "fa" ) chat <- chat_session(model_type = "fa", provider = "ollama", model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud") result1 <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = model1, variable_info = var_info1) result2 <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = model2, variable_info = var_info2)

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
text: fa (Factor Analysis): psych::fa(), psych::principal(), lavaan::cfa/efa(), mirt::mirt() gm (Gaussian Mixture): yet implemented irt (Item Response Theory): yet implemented cdm (Cognitive Diagnosis Models): yet implemented

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
text: provider model exposed top-level parameters convenience, dual interface pattern allows argument passed either directly respective configuration object (llm_args, fa_args, output_args). keeps primary signature clean maintaining flexibility

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(psych) fa_model <- fa(mtcars[,1:4], nfactors = 2, rotate = "oblimin")  var_info <- data.frame(   variable = c("mpg", "cyl", "disp", "hp"),   description = c("Miles per gallon", "Cylinders", "Displacement", "Horsepower") )  # Pattern 1: Fitted model result1 <- interpret(   fit_results = fa_model,   variable_info = var_info,   provider = "ollama",   model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # Pattern 2: Structured list # Extract loadings from fitted model loadings <- as.data.frame(unclass(fa_model$loadings))  # Option A: Loadings only (orthogonal rotation) result2a <- interpret(   fit_results = list(loadings = loadings),   variable_info = var_info,   model_type = "fa",   provider = "ollama",   model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # Option B: Loadings + factor correlations (oblique rotation) result2b <- interpret(   fit_results = list(     loadings = loadings,     factor_cor_mat = fa_model$Phi   ),   variable_info = var_info,   model_type = "fa",   provider = "ollama",   model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # Pattern 3: Chat session (token-efficient for multiple analyses) chat <- chat_session(model_type = "fa", provider = "ollama", model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud") result3a <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = fa_model, variable_info = var_info) result3b <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = fa_model2, variable_info = var_info2) print(chat)  # Check token usage } # }
